Accrington Stanley

Story of the summer This summer has been the first in recent memory in which we have had a full squad signed up, more or less, before the end of July. For other clubs, a fulsome roster is viewed flippantly; however for Accrington it marks a progression in the professional ethos of the club and its ability to attract players. Perhaps the signing of the summer so far has been Aristote 'Toto' Nsiala upon his release from Everton. The Congolese centre-half brought his full blooded approach to the Crown Ground in a loan spell last season which saw hearty performances dotted with disciplinary indiscretions. A talented player expected to springboard onto greater things than Fleetwood away.

What the fans want The Stanley fans aren't like the fans of most other clubs. Seeing our club go from Frickley to Fulham encourages a somewhat cultured worldview. We are patient and have a positive approach to expectation, mostly. We ask for no more than committed performances and football played in the right way. Paul Cook seems to be delivering that superbly.

What they'll actually get An up-and-down season with a late purple patch strong enough to average out the youthful inconsistencies in the side. At best, a play-off push. At worst, a gentle slip into the bottom half. There'll be an injury crisis or two with emergency loans aplenty; making cult heroes from reserve team footballers. Marvellous.

One to watch Luke Clark is an exciting midfield talent. Signed from Preston North End with Evertonian roots, there is a pedigree about the player and a skilful touch. If he comes through the rough and tumble of basement league football, we could have a real bright spark in our midst.

We'll finish … In the top half of the table. A cheeky eighth, perhaps. Nay, let's say sixth. Why not?

Andrew O'Mara, andrewomarafootball

Aldershot

Story of the summer Dean Holdsworth committing to the club after being linked with numerous other posts (most notably Creepy) was welcome news. He's not everyone's cup of tea but knows how to run a club of our limited means. For the first time in several seasons, we've got a bit of depth to our squad. With Craig Reid and Guy Madjo we also stand a bit of a chance of scoring, which makes a change.
What the fans want Most Shots fans are realists. A run at the play-offs, playing the kind of attacking football that marked our promotion campaign of a few years ago would keep almost everyone happy. We'd also like a bigger crowd. We're never going to get anywhere on an average crowd of 2,800.
What they'll actually get Mid-table in front of crowds of 2,800 with inexplicable patches of form where we're unable to score for games at a time.
One to watch Like many other teams at this level, the use of long term loans is rife, but Hull's Sonny Bradley is a cracking player.
We'll finish… As ever, 'it's a poor league this year'. Upper mid-half, missing out on a play-off spot in the last two games.
Finsbury Park, Aldershot fan

AFC Wimbledon

Story of the summer Well, that's got to be more comings and goings than Grand Central Station and the building of a new all-seater stand. After under-performing for most of the season, on what was to become known as Black Tuesday, 8 May, 14 first team players we released and Dons fans started to sweat. Terry Brown then slowly began to rebuild his decimated squad with some more experienced league players rather than the 20-year-olds that seemed to be taking over Kingsmeadow last season. Nothing wrong with 20-year-olds you understand, but as the saying goes, you don't win anything with kids. We're also building a new all-seater stand at the Kingston Road end of the ground which will help us become compliant with the leagues rules and regulations regarding fans and seating. This week the club also announced it's intention to convert Wimbledon greyhound stadium to our new permanent home. It'll be a long process but Plough Lane is where we belong.

What the fans want Optimistically we want the play-offs. There are experienced quality players like Warren Cummings, Stacy Long and Mat Mitchel-King at the Dons now and if Sammy Moore and Jack Midson keep up last season's good work we could end up in the play-offs.

What we'll actually get I think it will be a tough season. People found us out last year. I think we'll just miss out on the play-offs but not by too much. Personally, I'm in no rush for the club to get promoted – we don't want to rise too quickly because slow and steady wins this particular race. I also think that as long as Dons fans see some progress on and of the field we'll be happy.

One to watch Jim Fenlon has impressed me this pre-season. He looks like he could be quite a good attacking wing back. Good solid defensive work as well.

We'll finish.... ninth and I'll be happy with that.

Glyn Roberts, AFC Wimbledon fan

Barnet

Story of the summer Survival on the final day of the season for the third year running sparked a mass clear out of playing staff and backroom staff alike, with caretaker manager Martin Allen, assistant manager Guiliano Grazioli, and captain Mark Hughes, all departing the club. In Mark Robson, we have appointed a highly regarded young coach, who has focused primarily on bringing in young talent from the youth teams of the likes of West Ham and Charlton. The style of football during pre-season couldn't be any more different to the tactics employed by last season's manager Lawrie Sanchez, with players playing the ball to feet, and real work ethic evident throughout the team.

What the fans want Most fans would simply be happy with mid-table obscurity, but as a minimum the last day scramble for survival has to be avoided. This is our last season at Underhill and after what supporters have had to endure for the last three seasons, the club owe the supporters a season with at least some highs, and demonstrate that the club is moving in the right direction.

What they'll actually get Whilst pre-season's been encouraging in terms of our attacking play, defensively we still look short of what's required to survive in League Two. Mark Robson clearly has contacts in the higher leagues and our ability to finish in mid-table will largely be down to how well he can play the loan system. Mid-table isn't an unachievable target, but the squad at present is far from complete if this target is to be achieved.

One to watch In Jordan Brown we have an outstanding left-back who could easily push on, and Anthony Edgar's attacking flair has also caught the eye during pre-season, but the one to watch for me will be Ahmed Abdullah – a tough tackling holding midfielder and product of the West Ham youth system.

We'll finish … Personally I struggle to see us finishing any higher than 13th, and that's not being disrespectful to our new coach or new playing staff. Some fans have suggested goals will be a problem, but I'm more concerned with our ability not to let them in. At this stage, I have to show some faith and predict an 18th place finish – that's success as far as I'm concerned!

Jeff Searle, Barnet fan

Bradford City

Story of the summer Phil Parkinson has had a busy summer. I don't think any City fans were surprised by the released/retained list however I know some were panicking at the relatively slow start to the summer recruitment. I'll miss Lee Bullock and to an extent Michael Flynn, though the replacement signings are impressive. Season ticket sales were low before the surprise announcement that we'd signed Andrew Davies, followed by Rory McArdle, Gary Jones, Garry Thompson, Stephen Darby and perhaps disappointingly Will Atkinson. I think PP has made some astute signings and the squad has quality, if not a great deal of depth. James Meredith is one to watch and York fans were surprised he signed for City, after attracting interest from the Championship. The recent re-signing of Nathan Doyle is a good move – he was our player of the season in 2006-07. Alan Connell from Swindon is a surprising move, given he finished as their top scorer last season.

What the fans want Promotion, in style. Swashbuckling, attacking football, with teams coming to Valley Parade and leaving humiliated, after another thrashing. In all seriousness, promotion in third spot or the play-offs would make the majority of us happy, given the underachievement of the last 12 or so years. A nice cup run with a few local derbies, like last season, would be a welcome distraction too.

What they'll actually get I'm optimistic. If we can keep Nahki Wells and give James Hanson the service he needs, I think they'll bag 20 goals each. We've got a lot of quality this season and I have a lot of faith in Parkinson – promotion it is!

One to watch Nakhi Wells. Finished the season in style with 12 goals. What he lacks in size, he more than makes up for in ability. He's strong, quick, confident and composed. I can see him in the Championship in a couple of years (hopefully with City).

We'll finish … Second or third.

Ben Hoole, Bradford fan

Bristol Rovers

Story of the summer After taking over the reins from Paul Buckle in the middle of last season, new manager Mark McGhee inherited a squad made up largely of loan players, many of whom did not put pen to paper for a future at the club come the close of a rather disappointing 2011-12 season. The squad depleted rapidly as the likes of Cian Bolger, Aaron Downes and Tom Parkes were all retained by their parent clubs, while regular first-team faces Gary Sawyer and Craig Stanley left the club for pastures new. Also out the exit door was Chris Zebroski and, most recently, Mustapha Carayol, the latter of which was a big blow for the club, albeit not financially. The rumour mill hinted at a move for the creative livewire back in May, so it was no surprise when he jumped two divisions to join Middlesborough. However, for every player to leave the club, one has stayed. McGhee retained a handful of last season's promising players, including Lee Brown, Danny Woodards and Oliver Norburn. In terms of new blood at the club, the boss has dipped into the waters of international talent to add Faroe Islands international central defender Rogvi Baldvinsson and start negotiations with German midfielder Fabian Broghammer after his trial period at the club. McGhee also used his Scottish roots to bring Garry Kenneth and Dave Clarkson to the club.

What the fans want After the team fell drastically short of last season's predictions, the general consensus among fans now seems to be split 50-50. The more optimistic of fans will, once again, expect a promotion push while the other half are adamant not to start considering glory for fear of being disappointed if the club produce another average season.

What they'll actually get Realistically, you'd be foolish to overlook Rovers as a strong team in League Two this year. While we start the season in a similar situation to that of last year – in terms of stepping onto the pitch with a largely new-look squad who need time to gel under a still relatively new management – there is a different feeling on the terraces. McGhee has the fans' belief and, providing he can ensure the team click early on in the season, there's no reason we cannot push on and challenge the top of the table.

One to watch Shaquille Hunter could be one to keep an eye on this year. Six months ago, this 16-year-old wouldn't put pen to paper for a professional contract at the club but, after talking with Scott Sinclair, who started his career at the club before being bought by Chelsea, he later agreed to a deal that will become effective once he turns 17 at the end of August. The youngster is tipped to capably fill the shoes of his left-wing predecessor Carayol.

We'll finish … Fourth or fifth. Rovers recovered from the disappointment of relegation and found their feet in this league last season and that, plus the addition of a motivated new manager and experienced players, should all point in the direction of success. I don't think we'll storm the league the way some may expect us to, but I do predict we will be a force to be reckoned with and finish in a play-off spot comfortably. If we manage that, I wouldn't bet against us winning at Wembley a la 2007 as, as history has shown, we generally step up to the big occasions.

Maria Hudd, Bristol Rovers fan (@MariaHudd)

Burton Albion

Story of the summer Once the uncertainty of the Brewers' managerial post had been cleared up, new permanent boss Gary Rowett wasted no time in stamping his mark on the club after taking the reins from Paul Peschisolido. Several players were released and fresh impetus arrived in the shape of Robbie Weir, Zander Diamond, Damien McCrory, Marcus Holness, Dean Lyness and Lee Bell. It was no mystery that Albion's problems lay at the back – besides, they held the ignominious accolade of League Two's worst defence last campaign – but the capture of three defenders has gone some way to solving that issue. Hopefully.

What the fans want With a couple of gruelling, relegation-haunted seasons fresh in the memory, anything comfortable and vaguely stress-free (I don't think that's possible) would be welcome. Personally, I am craving a successful top-half finish – something we are yet to achieve as a Football League club. Anything better should be considered a significant bonus.

What they'll actually get Scoring goals is unlikely to be an issue so, if we can stop conceding them, who knows? That'll be the key. Overall, I don't see us as relegation contenders (unlike the bookies) though, perhaps, promotion may be a step too far.

One to watch Matty Palmer. A young central midfielder breaking through from Albion's youth set-up, Rowett has already hailed his skill on the ball as "the best at the club". He'll certainly be in and around the first team squad.

We'll finish … I'll play safe and opt for a solid mid-table finish.

Luca Gallone, burtonfootballnut (@lucabafc)

Cheltenham Town

Story of the summer Like the Mounties, Mark Yates always gets his man – and this has been the case with the arrivals of Shaun Harrad and Chris Zebroski. He tried to sign Zebroski last January, and when he got wind that the 25-year-old might be available, he pounced quickly. Same goes for Harrad, a prolific scorer at Burton, but a player who has then seen his career go awry, first at Northampton, and then at Bury, who say he is not in their plans and have allowed him to come to Whaddon Road. That will be our gain if Yates can get him firing and he is good for 15-plus goals – and with the pace of Zebroski, Jermaine McGlashan and Kaid Mohamed, as well as the creativity of Sam Deering and Marlon Pack, goals should not be a problem. Deering was always impressive against us for Barnet, and will bring more guile to our midfield, and Billy Jones has come in to be first-choice at left-back with loanee Luke Garbutt now back at Everton. Jones will be the only new face in the first-choice back four, with Alan Bennett and Steve Elliott solid at centre-half and at right-back cult hero Sido Jombati is looking to enhance his growing reputation. Behind them, there is no Jack Butland – Rubies fans were proud to see him star for Team GB this summer, as well as going to Euro 2012 – but Scott Brown ended last season in top form and has maintained that in pre-season. Yates is still looking for back-up to Brown, and wants another central midfielder to complete his squad – but on paper it looks a stronger group with more competition for places than last season.

What the fans want At the very least, the fans want to be in play-offs again after last season's near miss. But the expectation level has risen, and many fans believe the Rubies should be going all-out to get into the top three.

What they'll actually get League Two seems to get tougher every season, and with Fleetwood coming up with some impressive signings and Rotherham keen to make their mark in their new stadium, as well as Bristol Rovers, Bradford, Gillingham and Oxford looking to improve and relegated sides Wycombe, Chesterfield and Exeter out to bounce straight back, it will be a tough ask to make the top three. I think the Rubies will be in the top 10, and challenging for the play-offs.

One to watch Sido Jombati. The Portuguese right-back came in from Bath, and once he got his place in the side he quickly became a cult hero, and got an extended contract. If he maintains his form, he will attract some higher-division scouts for sure.

We'll finish … Somewhere in the top 10. If we get off to a good start and hit the straps quickly we can challenge for the top three, but we need to guard against tailing off as we did towards the end of last season. Personally, I will be delighted with another play-off place and view anything on top of that as a bonus.

Mark Halliwell, Cheltenham Town Chatter

Chesterfield

Story of the summer Not surprisingly revolution has been in the air following the disappointment of last season's relegation. Ten players were shown the door including stalwarts Derek Niven and Gregor Robertson, as well as a couple that flattered to deceive last term in Jimmy Juan and Alex Mendy. A deliberate thinning of the squad has meant fewer arrivals, however those that have joined look quality additions. Striker Marc Richards is a proven 20-goals-a-season striker who is more than welcome after the side desperately missed a goal scorer last season. Former Leeds and Doncaster Rovers defender Sam Hird looks another quality addition and has been installed as captain. Other recruits include midfielder Sam Togwell from Scunthorpe, defender Terrell Forbes from Leyton Orient and goalkeeper Richard O'Donnell from Sheffield Wednesday. It's nice to see three players from the youth team being awarded professional contracts with Jacob Hazel, Jonathan Wafula and Jack Waddle, the son of former England international Chris, being given their chance to shine. It looks like John Sheridan has gone for quality rather than quantity and fingers crossed the wrongs of last term can be put right.

What the fans want Simple – promotion. An immediate return to League One is a reasonable expectation having won this league so convincingly only a couple of years ago. Quality and experience seems to have been added to a trimmer looking squad giving fans every reason to be quietly optimistic.

What they'll actually get With changes to the squad and having to readjust to life back in League Two, fans may have to be patient while Sheridan finds a winning formula. Unfortunately that's one thing a lot of fans will be struggling to offer him as the disappointment from last season will no doubt linger until results and performances give hope. I'm confident we'll be there or there about's come the end of the season and an automatic spot is not out of the question.

One to watch I'm going to go with the same player I tipped to breakthrough last season and that's striker Jordan Bowery. He was by far the most improved player last season and was one of the few players to come out of the mess we made for ourselves with some credit. He led the line with pace and power after an injury then a suspension left Jack Lester missing for a lot of the season. His only problem may be getting in the side with a fit Jack Lester and new signing Marc Richards standing in his way.

We'll finish … Last seasons prediction of mid-table, possibly pushing for play-offs was way off the mark. Therefore take this with a huge pinch of salt but I feel slightly more confident in predicting a minimum of a play-off place.

Dean Mansell, Away End

Dagenham & Redbridge

Story of the summer The summer started with a clearout, as veterans Jon Nurse and captain Mark Arber were not offered new deals, along with other first-team regulars Damien McCrory and Peter Gain. Further exits in the shape of Adam Cunnington, Richard Rose, Gavin Tomlin and Ahmed Abdulla mean we've drastically trimmed our oversized squad, whilst only Gavin Hoyte and youngster Andrew Burns have arrived. Although injuries and a little desperation led us to keeping such a large number of players towards the end of last season, there is definitely some cost-cutting occurring here and we may lack a little cover in some areas. The biggest plus point of the summer has been securing some of our prized assets on long contracts. New captain Abu Ogogo, midfielder Billy Bingham, and forwards Brian Woodall and Dwight Gayle have all signed three-year deals.

What the fans want … After last season's disaster we aren't looking beyond mid-table. If we can keep our players fit it should be achievable, but that isn't a given after the huge amount of serious injuries we picked up last time around. I think we are also hoping some of our players can kick on and fulfil their potential with a slightly more attractive brand of football. Mickey Spillane is superb at keeping possession from centre-half with his calm distribution on the floor, and the likes of Bingham, Matt Saunders and Dominic Green are skilful and comfortable on the ball.

What they'll actually get I wouldn't be surprised if we are fighting at the wrong end of the table for at least part of the season. We will be asking a lot of a young squad to play consistently at this level, and inevitably some very inexperienced players will have a part to play at some stage. There may be a lot of pressure on Woodall's shoulders after he grabbed 13 goals in his first season as a pro, with Sam Williams lacking goalscoring pedigree, Josh Scott struggling with form since serious injury and Gayle still unproven.

One to watch Dwight Gayle is the obvious candidate after scoring 42 goals on loan at Bishop's Stortford last season. There is real excitement at Victoria Road that he could be our next big star although we must be careful to ease him in. If Dominic Green can stay injury free I'm also tipping him to tap into the huge potential that saw him sold to Peterborough in his first spell with us.

We'll finish Last time around I said 10th which proved incredibly optimistic, so this time I'm going to back off a little and say 14th.

Mark, We Only Need Nine Men

Exeter City

Story of the summer On paper the spine of the team - Richard Duffy, David Noble, Daniel Nardiello, James Dunne and Troy Archibald-Henville - have departed, but while these are all talented players they were part of a squad that didn't gel. Pat Baldwin and Alan Gow have signed permanently while other signings such as Kevin Amankwaah, Arron Davies and Tommy Doherty may not be marquee names but are possibly the sort of unfussy signings Exeter need. At the time of writing, another striker would be nice though, and it's not out of the question Jamie Cureton could return for another spell.

What the fans want A lot of the younger or more optimistic fans expect us to bounce straight back into League One, either via the play-offs or automatically. The older, more realistic fans would take top half with a tilt at the play-offs.

What they'll actually get A wild swing between despair when we lose our first two games, convincing everybody we'll be relegated, and elation when we occupy second in November before everything grinding to a halt for an anticlimactic mid-table finish.

One to watch Teenager Tom Nicholls had a decent loan spell at Dorchester, regularly finding the back of the net. Director of football Steve Perryman rates him highly and it wouldn't be a shock if he hit double figures.

We'll finish On the fringes of the play-offs, probably falling around three points short

Gary Andrews, @gafootbl

Fleetwood Town

Story of the summer After the euphoria of last season it's back to reality and back down to hard work for the manager, players and members of the club's board. Valuable team members of recent seasons in Gareth Seddon, Sean Clancy have departed, as has the best ever non-league player in Jamie Vardy, who has moved to Leicester for a seven figure sum. Special mention should also go to Richard Brodie who scored a few important goals for us. But we needed some experience, and the signings of what will be hopefully great League Two players in Damien Johnson, Jon Parkin, Barry Nicholson and Steven Gillespie have made teams in League Two sit up and take note that we are not here to make up the numbers.

What the fans want Tough one with it being are first season ever in the Football League. Some say top 10, some say play-off shake-up, some want automatic and the title! In my honest opinion, with the squad and signings made, I will be very disappointed if were are not in top seven come the end of season.

What they'll actually get I believe the fans will get a top seven finish and that would represent a great debut season regardless of what other fans from Fleetwood or other teams may say (I would actually love a trip to Wembley, as would many of the younger fans who never experienced the FA Vase final in 1985).

One to watch We have had a few promising youngster who have come and gone without a whisper – Adam Sumner, Joe Camozzi and Jack Duggan to mention a few – but going of what I hear from people within and around the club there are high hopes for new first year pro Jamie Allen. He's got great skill and ability and has made an impression within the first team squad already by all accounts, so we'll be hoping he works hard and gets a chance to shine.

We'll finish … Somewhere between third and fifth.

Sean Slater, Fleetwood Town fan

Gillingham

Story of the summer Found guilty of racial discrimination, temporarily evicted from their training ground and a two-month wait to discover the identity of Andy Hessenthaler's replacement as manager – it would probably be fair to say that Gillingham FC have had better summers. Six wins out of seven pre-season games since Martin Allen's belated arrival has helped to bring back a little of that feelgood factor, although strengthening one or two key positions with some of the funds from Paulo Gazzaniga's sale to Southampton would see the optimism increase further. Strikers Deon Burton and Ben Strevens, goalkeeper Stuart Nelson and Allen's son Charlie have arrived at the club after a trimming of the squad saw many of the old guard moved on, but hanging on to fans' favourite Jack Payne could yet prove to be the most significant story of the summer.

What the fans want The answer to that question is simple: a meaningful push for promotion. For the past two seasons Gillingham have promised much but delivered very little, with consecutive eighth-place finishes underlining our propensity for flattering to deceive. An automatic spot might be pushing it, but a season setting the pace amongst the play-off pack rather than straggling behind ought to keep the majority happy.

What they'll actually get Hopefully just that. Mad Dog might be famed for excelling in relegation battles rather than promotion campaigns, but he seems to have wasted no time in identifying and addressing the key failings that let us down last year. His emphasis on fitness, tactical organisation, and passing football ought to see an improvement both on the pitch and in the league table.

One to watch Adam Birchall is looking sharp and eager for a second tilt at league football having missed the whole of last season with a serious knee injury sustained shortly after his arrival from Dover. Also keep an eye out for Bradley Dack who is sure to be the next academy product pushing for some first-team action.

We'll finish… Blind faith is never stronger than at this time of year, but I genuinely believe that we'll be in the mix. I'll go for fifth.

Tom Clee @tomclee13 Gills 365

Morecambe

Story of the summer The two biggest departures of the summer have been Lawrence Wilson who left in search of football at a higher level (and ended up at Rotherham) and Garry Hunter who was released after nine years of service to the club. Phil Jevons and Paul Scott also left the club before the end of last season. In their place, we have brought in Bradford's Robbie Threlfall, Scunthorpe's Andy Wright and Crawley's Richard Brodie. Once again we are going with a reduced squad this year which means we are going to be heavily relying on youth and/or hoping we do not have an injury crisis.

What the fans want Optimistically, Morecambe fans would hope for a top-half finish, perhaps pushing for a play-off place. An improved home record from the last couple of seasons would be most appreciated having only won six times at home last season. Kevin Ellison to win the Golden Boot would be great too!

What they'll actually get Realistically, this is looking like our toughest season yet with an even smaller squad and one that is heavily relying on younger players. After showing relegation form for the last seven months of the previous season, we must start the season well to avoid getting into a scrap at the bottom of the table.

One to watch Andy Fleming had a torrid time with injuries last season but is looking sharp in pre-season. We are also hoping young strikers Jordan Burrow and Jack Redshaw will make a big contribution this year.

We'll finish Lower-mid table.

Jack Steer, Morecambe fan (@morecambejack)

Northampton Town

Story of the summer It's been an eventful summer at Sixfields with plenty released and a smaller squad being built by Aidy Boothroyd for his first full season in charge. Chris Hackett and Ishmel Demontagnac have been brought in to give us pace going forward whilst Clive Platt's arrival from Coventry should give Bayo Akinfenwa some stiff competition up front. The big departure was that of Michael Jacobs who rejected a new contract in order to join Derby County.

What the fans want I think a place in the top half would be very welcome after two seasons of relegation battles with the more optimistic fans looking at an outside shout of the play-offs.

What they'll actually get Realistically I do think we should be able to avoid another season of struggle and with the squad that we've put together so far and a full season under Boothroyd there's no reason why we can't improve and progress in the league this season.

One to watch With Jacobs gone, the one that might come through is striker Lewis Wilson who was starting to feature at the back end of last season.

We'll finish … Top half

Danny Brothers, A Load of Cobblers

Oxford United

Story of the summer　Steadying the ship is the order for this summer with minimal movements in and out on the playing side. The most eye-catching signing has probably been Sean Rigg from Port Vale. The winger/striker bagged double figures for the Valiants last season and a number of clubs were chasing his signature. His pre-season form indicates Oxford may have got themselves a bargain. Aside from this, new chairman Ian Lenegan has moved from his position as non-executive director to push the club forward. He has stated his intention to emulate his success at Wigan Warriors rugby club with a host of exciting changes in the offing.

What the fans want Promotion is the only aim. Lenegan has demanded it and Oxford fans crave it. With a late season collapse seeing United miss out on the play-offs last season, the same must not happen again. Perhaps top spot is beyond the team, but a top three finish is a must.

What they'll actually get It is not unrealistic for Oxford to finish in the automatic spots. Many in and around the club blame an injury list as long as your arm for last season's disappointing end and one of Lenegan's key measures is to improve fitness in the whole squad.

One to watch Youth development has taken a battering at the club during the wilderness years, so it's slim pickings. However, Tyrone Marsh is on the fringes and could be called upon if injuries and suspensions play a part.

We'll finish … Heavy investment in state-of-the-art sport science equipment and software should see an Oxford side capable of lasting the distance this time round. We'll finish third.

Tony Fallows, RageOnline

Plymouth Argyle

Story of the summer It's been a quiet one, as the club slowly finds its feet after the chaos of the last three years. Carl Fletcher, who continues as manager after signing a new Guardiola-style rolling contract, has declined to splash the cash in the transfer market; with the horrors of administration fresh in the memory, financial prudence has been the order of the day at Home Park and a compensation payment to Woking for Paris Cowan-Hall is the closest Argyle have come to coughing up a transfer fee. The 21-year-old forward has been followed by four more free signings in the form of goalkeeper Rene Gilmartin, midfielder Jamie Lowry, winger Andres Gurrieri and Welsh Premier League goal machine Rhys Griffiths. Captain Simon Walton has departed for Hartlepool, knocking a hefty chunk off the wage bill.

What the fans want A season free from relegation worries, ideally with a bit of a play-off push, would do us nicely. And 12 points from the games with Torquay and Exeter wouldn't go amiss either.

What they'll actually get The defensive unit that played such a vital part in last season's successful battle against the drop should keep us out of the relegation dogfight this time around. What can be achieved beyond that is likely to depend on the quality of whichever attacking players Fletch can bring in on loan.

One to watch Luke Young forced his way into the team as a wide midfielder during the second half of last season; the 19-year-old is now hoping for the chance to impress in his favoured central position.

We'll finish … Lower mid-table.

Mark Anderson, Argyle Outsider

Port Vale

Story of the summer Summer transfers have been overshadowed by events off the pitch. The coronation of Keith Ryder as the club's new owner once looked a formality, but at time of writing it still hasn't happened. Events reached farcical proportions as Ryder continues to promise to conclude the deal in 24 hours and Vale fans worry that the club may have to start the season in administration and running out of money. Throw in a thinly veiled attack by the city council (who underwrote administration), fan infighting plus the controversy of the club attempting to hold friendlies behind closed doors and you have all the ingredients of a highly controversial summer.

What the fans want Stability as the fanbase was badly fragmented following the protests against the former board. The Supporters Club have done an excellent job in trying to unite the fans but divisions remain. If Keith Ryder can deliver success on the pitch, then that may finally reunite the Vale supporters.

What they'll actually get The protracted summer takeover is only going to make it harder for the new owner (if we get one) to turn things around. On the pitch, Vale will have to replace the goals of the departed Marc Richards which may prove harder than some believe.

One to watch I think this could be a big season for Jennison Myrie-Williams. His career so far has been fits and starts, so I'm hoping that regular first-team football at Vale will bring the best out of him.

We'll finish … I've said "top-half with hopefully a play-off push" in the last two season previews. Let's hope I'm third time lucky …

Rob Fielding, One Vale Fan

Rochdale

Story of the summer It's been a funny summer at Rochdale with plenty of ups and downs. Of course we had relegation to come to terms with and the inevitable exit of a number of key players. Perhaps most difficult was the departure of captain Gary Jones who left for Bradford City. Our pre-season games were a bit hit-and-miss with a lot of trialists and younger lads being given chances, and the only game we seemed to play at full strength was our 3-1 win against Burnley. In the past couple of weeks we seem to have lifted our spirits slightly, John Coleman has made a few decent signings including a number of young loanees who will be interesting to see develop and a few days ago we signed Dele Adebola who we hope will bring us a bit more experience.

What the fans want Obviously, as all football fans, we want promotion. We don't want another 36 consecutive seasons in the bottom rung of the Football League and I don't think we deserve that either. We want to see passion and drive from the players, and want to see Rochdale back up there like we were a couple of seasons ago.

What they'll actually get I see us doing quite well. The team is fairly young with a few mature players thrown into the mix along with an experienced management team with knowledge of this level. There will be struggles along the way, I don't doubt that, but I also see plenty of highs too and I think we'll get a pretty exciting season with a new team to get to know.

One to watch We've brought in a few loan signings from Premier League clubs so they'll be interesting to keep an eye on – Joe Rafferty from Liverpool, Ryan Edwards from Blackburn Rovers and Rhys Bennett from Bolton. I also see Andrew Tutte developing a lot this season, especially as he's been named vice captain.

We'll finish … I'd hope that we'd aim at least for a top half table finish. Although the squad is pretty much completely new, manager John Coleman has a lot of experience in League Two that I think will prove pivotal for us this season. Ideally, I'd like to see us challenging in a play-off position.

Sarah Lomas, GirlOnATerrace (@GirlOnATerrace)

Rotherham United

Story of the summer What else could it be? We're going home at last! Don Valley Stadium was a means to an end, and it allowed the club to continue, but it's good to be back in our own stadium. The New York stadium looks truly stunning and it will hopefully be a joy to watch games there. Just as long as we don't run out to the Sinatra song. On the pitch, it's been another summer of upheaval with 10 new signings at the time of writing. I still don't like the fact that we have Steve Evans as our manager but he appears to have made some good signings if pre-season reports are to be believed. As long as we don't become reliant on a single goalscorer as we have the last couple of years, we should have a good shot at promotion.

What the fans want Probably the same as fans of most teams – some decent, attacking, passing football in a stadium with atmosphere.

What they'll actually get We'll certainly have an atmosphere to watch games in. DVS was renowned for being soulless. As for the football, if we can't be optimistic now when can we be? We've signed some pacey players as well as some who can keep the ball which bodes well for the style of football, though we do need to remember it's still League Two. The return of Ian Sharps should help strengthen the defence significantly.

One to watch The youth system has been neglected in the last few years. Whether he makes the breakthrough this year is unclear, but good things are being said about Mitchell Rose. Of the new signings, I'm looking forward to watching our new Icelandic international, Kari Arnason.

We'll finish ... Top three. Hopefully we'll win the title, but as long as we go up I don't really mind.

Phil Kyte, London Miller

Southend United

Story of the summer Having missed out on automatic promotion due to below-par home form and an unusually high points total for a top three place, Paul Sturrock has shaken up his squad for this season. Having lost Anthony Grant to Stevenage, Southend released around 12 players this summer including Liam Dickinson, whilst Bilel Mohsni created his own transfer saga having decided to leave Roots Hall. Sturrock has signed shrewdly in opting for proven League Two talent, having brought in Ryan Cresswell, Anthony Straker, Kevan Hurst, Gavin Tomlin and, of course, sealing the permanent return of local messiah Freddy Eastwood. However, with just a few days to go, Southend still haven't got a goalkeeper – a strategy that will surely overtake tika-taka as the in vogue footballing style this season!

What the fans want After last season's agonising conclusion, Southend fans will be hoping for nothing but promotion in 2013. The fans hope that if Freddy Eastwood gets fit, stays fit and returns to the form of his first spell at Southend, automatic promotion is a genuine possibility.

What they'll actually get A top seven finish appears most likely again this season. There is stiff competition yet again for the automatic places as League Two boasts two more big-spending teams in Fleetwood and Rotherham looking to match Swindon and Crawley's efforts last year. The management team will be particularly keen to avoid the play-offs again but may have to settle for that.

One to watch After missing all of 2011-12 through injury, the almost-forgotten man Barry Corr could return to strike fear into League Two defenders this season and replicate the 21 goals he scored during the 2010-11 season.

We'll finish … Play-offs minimum. Southend will at least match last season's efforts and will hope to better it, but significantly improved fortune in the play-offs will do just fine.

Lew Carey, Another Northern Sky

Torquay United

Story of the summer Just like this time last year we're having to deal with losing three of the previous season's outstanding performers. The formidable Bobby Olejnik's goalkeeping talents were wasted in League Two, while the bright young pair of centre-back Mark Ellis and midfield string-puller Eunan O'Kane also impressed sufficiently to justify testing themselves at a higher level. Plenty of talent remains however and Martin Ling looks to have done a respectable job of sourcing replacements, particularly the lively forward Billy Bodin who impressed on loan last season and should be capable of replicating O'Kane's attacking invention, although we still arguably lack depth in several areas.

What the fans want Most – myself included – will be hoping for a third consecutive play-off campaign. Even if our new signings don't sparkle to the same extent as their predecessors the continuity, momentum and harmony carried over from last season – plus the remaining funds from our summer player sales – should provide a solid platform.

What they'll actually get Something not altogether dissimilar provided that Martin Ling heeds the lessons of last season, where insufficient squad rotation and an over-reliance on defensive heroics saw us stutter towards the finish. Another inconsistent start or the loss of a key player to injury could well see us slip towards mid-table.

One to watch The manager has challenged exciting young winger Saul Halpin to fulfil his obvious potential. Tall for his position and with a flair for the unexpected, he has the ability to terrify unsuspecting full-backs.

We'll finish … Almost certainly in the top half. I was unduly pessimistic last season, so this time I'll throw caution to the wind and go for sixth place.

Ben Mayhew, Greenwich Gull and experimental361.com

Wycombe Wanderers

Story of the summer With relegation back to League Two officially confirming Wanderers as a 'yo-yo' club, by far the biggest story of the summer has been the takeover of the club by the Supporters Trust. The takeover has come eight years after a new dawn had been promised by the then board of directors, who bullied through a conversion to a plc and thus ended one of the last remaining supporter-owned clubs in the Football League. The last three of those eight years has seen Wanderers run by a single owner who racked up debts of more than £6m in the form of loans. The task of the Trust is to now get the club back on an even keel. A transfer embargo placed on the club for the non-filing of accounts, was only lifted following the Trust takeover at the end of June. Manager Gary Waddock promptly made six signings to replace a similar amount released at the end of the 2011-12 campaign. Perhaps the most familiar of those signed will be former Luton Town midfielder Matt Spring. Meanwhile, the future of top scorer Stuart Beavon at the club is still uncertain. He bagged 25 goals last season but with his contract running until June 2013, is expected to leave, either before the season starts or in the January transfer window. Beavon's form or replacement will be crucial in Wanderers aspirations for the new season in League Two.

What the fans want In an ideal world, the Trust takeover would prompt a return in local interest for the club and that spirit would lift the team to automatic promotion back to League One. Playing in a league lower than last season, should make that a possibility.

What they'll actually get With the Trust trying to cut losses of in excess of £1m per season, there will be little room for error if the new signings don't gel. Expensive loan signings, that have become almost obligatory in the second half of the season, may not be an option and fans may just have to settle for also rans in the promotion chasers.

One to watch With the Trust taking the bold step of scrapping the club's £600,000 loss making youth system, it's perhaps poignant that it's worth looking out for a couple of names that come though that system – midfielder Josh Scowen and defender Jesse Kewley-Graham.

We'll finish A wildly optimistic sixth but edged out in the play-offs.

Paul Lewis, Chairboys.co.uk

York City

Story of the summer After the elation of finally getting promotion back to the Football League this summer has been about subtle improvements rather than the wholesale changes of the last few seasons. As part of the investment in security surrounding the Olympics in London, the Health Protection Agency has been touting a state-of-the-art disease surveillance system promising real-time collection and analysis of health-related data to detect threats as early as possible. It tracks flu symptoms, rashes, vomiting, double vision, and other symptoms of infectious diseases.

The effort is laudable, and it makes good sense for an event as big as the Games.

But, when the Olympics are over, a more powerful and effective way of protecting the public from imminent health threats would be to apply that same innovative spirit and computational power to preventable chronic diseases and their associated risk factors. Heart disease, cholesterol, high blood pressure and obesity kill more people every day than infectious diseases.

This is partly a political reality. If five children die from meningitis during the London Olympics, the government would be attacked by the media, and officials would lose their jobs. Unfortunately, the roughly 250 heart attacks that will occur every day in England during the Olympics will cause no alarm at all.

In the US, a third of the 2.4m deaths annually are due to just two causes: heart disease and stroke. Yet there is no outcry. But after a handful of cases of whooping cough nationwide, agencies coast to coast mobilised against it. But this is changing.

More than a century ago, New York had this same infectious-disease mindset, but when cholera threatened to kill and maim in 1866, inspectors from the newly created metropolitan health department went door to door collecting people's clothes and burning them. They disinfected bathrooms, kitchens, and bedrooms. It worked; fatalities from cholera dropped 90% from the previous epidemic in 1849.

New York now leads the way in public health in fighting chronic diseases, with smoking bans, cooking oil restrictions, calorie counts on menus, and restrictions on the amount of soda that can be sold. We can debate the relative effectiveness of different policies, but the overall campaign is a winner: engage the community in a discussion of the importance of healthy behaviours, put policies in place that encourage those behaviours, and measure the impact of those policies.

And look what has happened to life expectancy: the average for men increased by 13.6 years between 1989 and 2009, the biggest improvement in the country. For women, the gain was 7.2 years, also the best. A big part of these gains is due to the successful control of infectious diseases, and especially HIV/Aids. But the public health approach to chronic disease is an important component that should be a model for other agencies worldwide.

This requires three steps

• Build consensus before going bold. If a city had tried to ban supersized sodas two decades ago, protesters would have flooded the streets with signs saying: "No taxation without carbonation!" New York leaders prepared their audience by showing them the damage being done by runaway calorie consumption.

• Prove the concept. Cities and states followed New York's lead in requiring calorie counts on menus. Studies have subsequently shown that when people read the calorie information, they generally choose lower-calorie items.

• Utilise your assets. One of the most exciting things about the infectious disease surveillance program launched in the UK is its use of aggregated data from physician visits by millions of patients. This is a big institutional and cultural leap from just a decade ago when governments were slow to detect and respond to Sars.

To track chronic diseases, the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) at the University of Washington is piloting a project working with the Seattle and King County health department that merges data sources from hospitals, clinics, and pharmacies. The main objective is to determine the causes of disparities in outcomes and to better develop programmes to control chronic diseases. We hope other cities, states, and countries follow suit to find the health disparities in their communities and address them.

Chronic diseases deserve the same attention as infectious diseases. Both are equally important and should be approached with the same vigour and high-tech innovation.

Ali Mokdad is professor of global health at the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) at the University of Washington and leads the survey and surveillance activities at the Institute

It's the men's marathon on Sunday, the final event of the Olympics, and you don't need a ticket to attend. Choose your route-side point here, but spare a thought for the East End.

Olympic marathons traditionally end inside the main games stadium. Had that tradition been maintained for London 2012, the hard-up host borough of Tower Hamlets would have hosted a major event, its residents could have lined its streets and enjoyed it for free, and a global TV audience would have seen and maybe learned a little about some of the capital's most important but not very glamorous historical sites.

When Locog declared in autumn 2010 that the course would be through tourist-attractive central London instead it felt like a snub to the very part of the city the Games is supposed to help most. The suspicion remains that the main reason for the decision was that a backdrop of Buck House was more marketable.

Tower Hamlets council complained and was handed the consolation of Brick Lane being dubbed London's "curry capital," but the story hasn't ended well. First, the Olympic torch relay didn't go down the famous street and now the expected influx of custom hasn't shown up. Restauranteurs have told the East London Advertiser that that "curry capital" has been a "dead city." It's been a fantastic Games, but that marathon decision remains a shame.

It's been a big year so far for British brands. With the Diamond Jubilee and the Olympics, many marketers have focused their campaigns on patriotism and building on the tangible energy and excitement. It's hard to find an advertisement or promotion where the product is not tied (however tenuously) to the event, from tablets at the opening ceremony to synchronised swimming in broadband packages.

But once the dust settles towards the middle of September, brands are going to be looking at what's next for their marketing campaigns. This means agencies need to start preparing now and they need to learn fast. Those agencies that are geared up and move quickly will have an advantage over their competitors.

The majority of the 5,000 marketing directors we interviewed in Q1 and Q2 of 2012 said they were waiting for the Jubilee and Olympic periods to be over before launching major initiatives, and there are many reasons for this.

Companies that did not secure sponsorship opportunities have been reluctant to launch major campaigns in a period where there is so much noise created by the sponsors that their messages to consumers are in danger of being drowned out. Many have decided to wait and see which messages and campaigns work throughout the Games so that they will be able to adjust their strategies accordingly.

For Olympic sponsors the experience has been different. Firstly, while sponsorship represents an unparalleled opportunity to boost their profiles and get in front of consumers, it is not all plain sailing, and they have to face some of the negative publicity that comes with the territory. A classic example is the backlash against McDonald's, which was recently accused of having a monopoly over chips in the Olympic Village.

A further pitfall of being an Olympic sponsor is the potential for hijacking and many non-Olympic brands are already pushing the limits of what's allowed. It has also opened the door to criticism for some sponsors like Coca-Cola and Cadburys, who are all accused of promoting unhealthy foods on a global platform.

Social media has been privy to a lot of this negative sentiment, so agencies will need to be aware that it may be a delicate subject for many brands, and adapt their standard social media pitch to reflect this.

Sponsors will be closely monitoring the returns on their substantial investments come the autumn, with particular focus on social media. At the time of the Beijing Olympics, Twitter had barely a million users, and Facebook was only a fifth of its current size. Most brands are still developing their social strategies and they are going to be very interested in the potential impact of social networks on their reputations this August. In fact, the entire business world will be watching social networks closely, and in addition to the obvious need for messaging refreshes (as the sports analogies and medal metaphors will simply no longer be relevant) there will no doubt be major online overhauls in the autumn as well.

Another unexpected turn of events that affected sponsors in the past weeks was the fantastic achievement of Bradley Wiggins in the Tour de France. Few marketing departments would have predicted two years ago when they signed their sponsorship deals that another sporting event just a week before the Games could threaten to steal their thunder. But, to the delight of the British population (and BSkyB — not an Olympic sponsor), Wiggins did just that – an enormous achievement.

For brands associated with the Olympics, the challenge will be how they can be repositioned. Will the current advertising focus on British heritage and patriotism be something they want to maintain, or will they go back to being more reserved in a typical 'British' manner? Perhaps the British hype may be seen as 'tacky' after the Games, or maybe this heightened sense of pride is part of the legacy. The most likely scenario, assuming the Games will be deemed a success, is that organisations will run two campaigns in parallel: national 'proud British' campaigns and international ones, capitalising on the success of the events.

At the same time, all the CSR and well being initiatives that have been launched in the run-up to the Games will need to be maintained, to ensure consistency of brand image, and so that sponsors can use the legacy in their campaigns for years to come. Companies neglect these at their peril, as the media will be keen on annual legacy reviews for at least the next ten Augusts.

Referring to the Olympics opening ceremony, Danny Boyle said he hoped it would reflect a country trying to "find its level" in the world. He mentioned how it needed to portray a 'modesty', and the show has been described as warm, witty and self-deprecating in a true British sense. Brands will now also be thinking about how to find their 'level' in the world, and will be looking to articulate a different notion of Britishness that resonates globally.

The message to suppliers in the marketing, advertising and communications industries is clear: come September, you will be expected to act quickly, analyse the impact of this unusual summer on the media industry and Brand Britain, and provide advice in uncharted territory as calls for an encore to the greatest show on Earth resound.

Anthony Cooper is managing director of business intelligence company Pearlfinders.

Africa once was an important exporter of raw peanuts. In the 1960s, the continent accounted for about 75% of the global trade; by 2005, that had figure had slumped to just 5%. Increased competition from America, Argentina and particularly China was part of the story. But stricter food safety controls from Europe also took their toll. In particular, European countries placed strict limits on the level of aflatoxins – a type of mycotoxin fungi – in peanuts, hitting countries such as Malawi.

Aflatoxins are a naturally occurring but highly toxic substance caused by fungi that grow on crops such as maize, paprika and peanuts (more commonly referred to as groundnuts in Africa). Contaminations can happen as a result of poor pre- and post-harvest practices, such as inadequate drying and storage. Poor-quality kernels – immature, shrivelled or damaged – are prone to contamination by aflatoxins.

There have been several reported cases of acute aflatoxicosis – where extremely high doses of aflatoxin have been ingested – associated with the consumption of contaminated homegrown maize. There were two outbreaks in Kenya – one in 1982, in which 12 people died, and one in 2004, in which 317 people became ill and 125 people died.

The UN's Food and Agriculture Organisation estimates that 25% of the world's crops are affected by mycotoxins, leading to chronic exposure for about 4.5 billion people, mainly in the tropics and subtropics.

The Centres for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Health Organisation estimate that approximately 80% of liver cancers – which are far more prevalent in the tropical and sub-tropical parts of the developing world – are related to aflatoxin consumption. Aflatoxins are also linked to increased susceptibility to maternal anaemia and childhood stunting. In west Africa, stunted or underweight children have aflatoxin levels that are 30% to 40% higher than in children of normal height and weight.

Studies conducted by the International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics (Icrisat) in southern India revealed aflatoxin levels as high as 40 times the permissible limit. Both groundnut haulms (crop residue) and cake made from crushed seeds are major sources of animal feed. This can lead to the contamination of milk in both urban and rural areas, potentially exposing a huge cross-section of the population, particularly children, to the effects of aflatoxins.

Yet food safety, according to Twin, a fair trade NGO, is neglected and should be firmly on the development agenda, particularly at a time when David Cameron is co-chairing the UN committee that will look at the post-2015 development agenda and leading the 2013 G8 meetings that will address food security and nutrition. The UK prime minister is also chairing the hunger summit on Sunday, making the most of the presence of world leaders at the Olympics closing ceremony.

Twin is currently working on food safety and food security in Malawi, focusing on groundnuts, but with wider implications for key staple crops such as maize. Malawi once had significant groundnut exports (up to 40,000 metric tonnes a year), but volumes have now dropped severely following the implementation of rigorous food safety standards in Europe. Twin's work in Malawi initially focused on improving the safety of groundnuts for the international market. As it learned more about aflatoxin contamination, however, its focus switched to making food safe for the domestic population.

"Concentrating on food security and nutrition are not enough," said Andrew Emmott, senior nut manager at Twin. "Nutrition is seen as a silver bullet, but, unless you look at the full range of issues including food safety, you've got a problem. Keeping contaminated food from being exported to Europe does not mean that you are keeping unsafe food out of the local population in Malawi."

Twin says 60% of groundnuts grown in Malawi are traded informally and consumed locally, and are not subject to any testing for aflatoxin. The same applies to trading and consumption of staples such as maize. Techniques for preventing contamination can be relatively simple. Groundnuts that are allowed to dry well immediately after harvesting tend to develop negligible levels of contamination, whereas groundnuts left out but covered with haulms and leaves tend to develop high levels of aflatoxin contamination. The most effective means of control is immediate removal of pods from harvested plants, but this is not always possible at a time when other farm activities are at their peak, so one possible option is the use of cheap dryers.

Donors have not entirely neglected aflatoxins. The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the UK's Department for International Development announced funding of $19.8m and $1.6m, respectively, in February to support the Partnership for aflatoxin control in Africa to look at solutions such as proper drying and storage.

I first started working on London 2012-inspired arts projects back in 2008 and since then have been privileged to have been part of the Cultural Olympiad in myriad forms. I have worked across all genres; brought sports and science together with the arts; involved over 200 artists and participants of all ages and backgrounds (including some of Team GB); and reached an audience of over half a million in the south-east alone.

From where I'm sitting, knowing this has been replicated UK-wide, the Cultural Olympiad can be viewed as a massive success. But during this whole experience, I've found myself having to justify this sports-initiated endeavour to many of my colleagues in the culture sector.

Interrogation was fiercest from those who resented the changed funding landscape: why was money being diverted from arts to sport? Those who saw no reason for dialogue between the two asked me to defend the creative collaboration. And to those who viewed the Olympics as elitist, I've have had to attest to the fact that they – or at least the Cultural Olympiad – were inclusive.

Of course, I was also in the fortunate position of telling artists I had money to give them for new 'arts-sports' commissions. Some responded with works directly linked to sports or London 2012, others created more tangential or abstract work. Either was fine by me. I viewed London 2012 as a cultural moment that demanded the critical engagement of the arts – this was my motivation to work in and around the Olympics from the off.

That's not to say my journey to Games time has been easy. I have worked with consummate professionals at every turn but I've also sat in meetings with six departments vying for authority. I have waited so long for press releases that the news moment has long gone and with it the opportunity to celebrate the arts. I have been asked to make the near-impossible happen after months spent waiting for a brief or a key decision to be made. I have been forced to play dictator to people trying simply to understand the rules behind the branding and creative rights. And I have looked for leadership, foresight and clarity and often found it lacking.

Then again, none of us had ever put on an Olympics before, let along one that was reaching out beyond sports to culture. It was bound to be a working environment of thinking on the spot.

One very real fear I had was the culture of privilege I encountered – that this might be the Olympic legacy the arts were left with. Numerous times I was told that artists should be biting their London 2012-branded arms off to be included. Numerous times an artist's daily rate was quoted below the market rate. Numerous times artists were expected to fund their own travel, accommodation and materials. Too often, the cost to artists for seizing this opportunity seemed to financial and moral loss.

Would this way of working become the norm post-Games: a culture that did not remunerate the arts, that saw it as the poor and subservient relation to sport? But the opening ceremony and the strength of the Cultural Olympiad at large should put pay to any doubts over parity of status. And with the likes of a-n, Air and the Guardian all bringing artists' rates to the fore, I hope I never have to fight the corner of an artist to be paid properly again.

We've all seen TwentyTwelve, so I'm sure I don't need to labour these points. Nor do I want to. We got there in the end. Jubilant at the superb show UK arts has put on for the wider world, I end my Olympic journey as I began it, believing in art's ability both to applaud and hold to account sporting endeavour, values and politics. To document, explore and challenge what the Games means to this country as well as be part of its collective celebration.

My true ambition when starting out with the Games in 2008 was that the Cultural Olympiad would quieten its own naysayers come 2012. Danny Boyle's opening ceremony was a calling card: fun, vibrant, provocative, subversive and high calibre. It encapsulated in one night all the London 2012 inspired projects I have been involved in. It felt like the arts had won the first gold of the Games and, to me at least, that the Cultural Olympiad had been vindicated.

None of that ceremony could have been delivered, on or off stage, without the prior generation of arts investment this country has enjoyed. Not only did it mark the start of the Games, it celebrated the depth, breadth and quality of the UK cultural community and sector. A community that has been under sustained stress in recent years, an easy target for austerity economics.

Beyond the spectacle of the ceremony, I hope audiences have been left in awe and support of our arts and that as a sector we have used the opportunity London 2012 afforded us to make our mark anew. We have invigorated existing and forged new connections, proving our value to those outside our immediate remit. Let's move forward into (still) uncertain times sure of that value ourselves.

Local authorities are awash with new financial freedoms. Councils recently took charge of their own housing stock and the associated rental income. The local government finance bill, working its way through parliament, will provide a direct link between local business rate growth and local authority finances. Controversial plans are under way to localise council tax support. With power being devolved in so many areas, why are ministers still reluctant to do the same with planning fees?

In November 2010 the government consulted on allowing councils to set their own planning application fees. Since then, nothing has been heard on the matter – at least on the government's side. Planners have been calling for the introduction of local fees ever since, while growing increasing fearful that the plans have been dropped at the centre. Their fears appeared to be confirmed in July when decentralisation minister Greg Clark announced fees would be increased by 15% across the board, in line with inflation.

Malcolm Sharp, president of the Planning Officers Society, says the announced increase is far from the solution that was hoped for. "Planning is being asked by the government to step up to the mark. We're all willing and ready to do that but if we're really going to do this effectively we need the resources. This is just going to help us keep the show on the road."

Recent planning reforms have introduced new responsibilities such as the requirement to submit applications for design review. Some local authority areas are inherently more complex for planning teams, meaning the application process is much more resource intensive. Councils are adamant that they must be allowed to recoup the true cost of dealing with applications from developers.

The evidence also suggests that developers are prepared to cover this cost. Last year, fed up with waiting for local fees to be introduced, Westminster city council struck a voluntary deal with Westminster Property Association. The group, which represents major developers in London's West End, agreed to contribute an extra £26,000 for major projects in return for guarantees over the time taken to process the application.

Despite the success of this arrangement, ministers have declined to formally extend the deal elsewhere. John Walker, operational director of development planning at Westminster, is unimpressed. "It's a fob off," he says of the 15% increase.

Walker believes ministers are concerned about introducing a policy which could result in increased fees and be seen as a brake on the economy. "It's only cost recovery, which I don't think is unreasonable," he says, pointing out that the money has to be found somewhere. "Why should the taxpayer be subsidising someone who's carrying out a major development?"

It wouldn't be the first time that planning policies have borne the hallmark of Treasury intervention. Sharp agrees that fears about the impact on economic growth played a part in the decision. "I can only think that the government feels local fees would have some dampening effect on development," he says.

Conversely, some suggest a uniform approach to fee setting could actually stifle development. Kate Henderson, chief executive of the Town and Country Planning Association, says pro-development councils may be hindered by the enforced 15% fee hike, which could add to the financial pressure on developers. "A blanket national increase may have implications for areas that are struggling with viability," she says. "In areas where there are more challenging sites, this may have an adverse impact."

In Westminster, Walker says feedback from developers on voluntary fee contributions has been positive and he is hopeful the council's deal will be renewed in October. He recommends others councils discuss similar proposals with local developers. Provided with guarantees over the quality of the service, many applicants will be prepared to stump up the extra cash.

For now, a more formal arrangement looks unlikely to be forthcoming. A spokesperson for the Department for Communities and Local Government claimed: "The government has balanced the need to ensure councils are properly resourced to assess planning applications, while reducing the burden on ordinary council taxpayers. These measures will enable councils to provide an efficient planning service and support the delivery of development and regeneration."

If ministers think the matter is dealt with, others remain unconvinced. "We will continue to press for an even fairer, more transparent, localised system for planning fees," says Clyde Loakes, vice-chair of the Local Government Association's environment and housing board.

It was four years ago that planning fees were last reviewed. It seems unlikely councils will put up with the lack of flexibility for that long again.

Last year, the people of Wales voted for the National Assembly for Wales to have primary law-making powers. Today, in 20 fields such as health, education, local government and the environment, the national assembly has the authority to legislate without Westminster. The executive itself is now separate from the assembly and shortly after the referendum rebranded itself the Welsh government. So today, I am calling on the National Assembly for Wales to be renamed the Welsh parliament.

In this, the week of the National Eisteddfod, the most important Welsh cultural event in the calendar, I feel it is now time to have a Welsh parliament. Polling and the recent referendum show that the electorate want an institution as strong as a parliament, and in reality the national assembly is in all but name the Welsh parliament.

Many may question why I as a proud unionist would call for such a move. I have never shied away from the fact that I believe the United Kingdom has been a force for good, where we have a richer and fairer society because we are united. Where the UK allows us a much bigger presence on the world stage, where as we have seen with the Olympics, the UK has so much to offer the world as a union. But, by the same measure, I and many in the Welsh Conservatives are proud to be Welsh. We are proud of our culture, language and heritage, and as a party are proud of devolution.

There can be no doubt too, that uncertainty with the Scottish referendum is having repercussions in Wales. Some in Wales do want to break away and go it alone. A recent poll, however, showed that only 7% of people in Wales do want to separate. I believe that the United Kingdom gives us strength as a community. When any part of the United Kingdom suffers a setback, the rest of the country stands behind it. From severe weather to economic setbacks, there is a community within our union that goes beyond the political to the emotional. It is because of strength of the UK that I believe now is the time to have a strong Welsh parliament in a strong United Kingdom.

So why now? Why change a name from assembly to parliament?

This isn't simply a rebrand for the sake of rebranding; this is a statement about the institution that now legislates for our great nation. The assembly deserves to be respected. It deserves the respect of the executive, and it deserves to be an institution that stands out. Some may question why there needs to be any change at all. There is a parliament in Scotland with primary law-making powers, so why not in Wales?

For years, confusion has understandably existed among the Welsh public in distinguishing between the Welsh assembly government and the National Assembly for Wales. The rebranding of WAG to Welsh government' has helped mitigate that, but we believe the time has come for Wales's devolved institution to lose the "assembly" tag and brand itself as a proper Welsh parliament – strengthening the distinction between legislature and executive, while giving it the accolade the people of Wales afforded it in last year's referendum.

The process for this to happen is very simple. One small amendment to the Government of Wales Act 2006 would be all that needs to happen to change the National Assembly for Wales into the Welsh parliament. No expensive rebrand, no new buildings, no more politicians, no new protocol, but what a statement it would be!

A statement that shows that Wales is a nation with a strong legislature in a strong United Kingdom.

When we look at other countries such as Australia, state parliaments operate alongside the national parliament. In the UK, we have the Scottish parliament and the Westminster parliament. There is no reason why we couldn't have the Welsh parliament, too.

So in this week of celebration of Welsh culture, I call on other leaders to consider this change. There is no hurry to overnight changes, but in 2016 wouldn't it be a great thing for the Welsh people to vote in elections for a Welsh parliament for the first time since the 15th century.

Some may say that this is just a name change, but I say that there is a lot in a name.

My wife is a successful research fellow. She is a world class researcher and has a strong publication record. She is a talented lecturer and is respected by her students. She collaborates with academic and industrial partners and is invited regularly to speak at conferences around the world. But when her funding runs out this October, the Russell Group university where she has worked for the last eight years is making her redundant. She is struggling to find another position. And it is my fault.

We call it the 'two body' problem, after the scenario in physics when a pair of particles interacts with each other. In our case, though, it comes about when the demands of an academic career collide brutally with the obligations of being but one half of a couple, with owning a home and with generally having a life. But while physicists can solve their two body problems with a few deft equations, the real life equivalent is significantly less tractable.

We have managed to cope reasonably well so far. I was happy to adopt the role of 'trailing spouse' so that my wife could develop her career. So when we stayed with her parents while she wrote up her doctoral thesis, I got a temporary job nearby. When she secured her first postdoctoral position at Warwick, I found a respectable graduate job down the road in Birmingham. And when she moved down to Bristol, I put in for a transfer to my employer's office in the city.

But this time things are different. I now run my own successful business and have developed strong ties to the area. I like our house, I like our garden and I like where we live. Moving somewhere new and starting again from scratch is really not a tempting option. So when my wife speaks of jobs in Manchester, Munich or Mississippi, I really want to be supportive. But deep down I just don't want to go. And, if we are being honest, neither does she.

My wife's colleagues seem less than sympathetic to our plight. 'Just go anyway', was the response from one. Another was presumably 'only trying to help' when he forwarded her details of positions in the United States. I don't know whether it is because my wife's fellow academics are mostly male, because they already have permanent posts or because they are not used to a two-career family, but I find their presumptions that she can simply pack her bags and move to another city, country or even continent particularly disturbing.

We cannot be the only couple in this position, forced to compromise the career of one so that the other may flourish. I can see that working in different research environments and with people from different backgrounds is a positive thing, but why does nobody seem to notice that having to postdoc in several countries before anyone will even consider you for a permanent lectureship – should such a thing even still exist in the current environment – is just not compatible with how most people want to live?

I have read in recent weeks a number of articles criticising the lack of diversity among academics and lamenting the 'leaky pipe' of, in particular, female researchers who complete a PhD or a first postdoctoral position only to then leave academia for something else.
